Title.evidence: Randomised Controlled Trial of CNI-Sparing Regimens in Kidney Transplantation

Trial_Design.evidence: Participants were randomised to either a CNI-sparing regimen or a standard CNI-based regimen.

Participants.evidence: This randomised controlled trial was conducted among kidney transplant recipients (KTRs) with low-to-moderate immunological risk.

Intervention.evidence: The intervention group received a CNI-sparing regimen, while the control group received standard CNI-based therapy.

Objective.evidence: To evaluate the impact of CNI-sparing regimens on long-term allograft function.

Method_Outcome.evidence: The primary outcome was allograft function at 12 months, assessed by estimated glomerular filtration rate (eGFR).

Randomisation_Allocation.evidence: Randomisation was computer-generated, and allocation was concealed.

Blinding.evidence: Outcome assessors were blinded to group assignments.

Number_Randomised.evidence: A total of 200 participants were randomised: 100 to the intervention group and 100 to the control group.

Number_Analysed.evidence: The analysis was conducted using an intention-to-treat approach.

Result_Outcome.evidence: The intervention group demonstrated improved eGFR (mean difference = 5.2 mL/min/1.73 m², 95% CI 3.1 to 7.3; p = 0.01).

Harms.evidence: Adverse events were mild, with 3% in the intervention group and 1% in the control group experiencing gastrointestinal side-effects.
